attributes.title: Histologic Changes in Surgical Pathology Specimens from Transgender and Gender Non-conforming Patients on Gender Affirming Hormone Therapy: A Scoping Review

attributes.title: Individual differences in the relationship between sleep and body image
attributes.description: This project will seek to explore the relationship between sleep and body image across different cohorts of the UK population. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to be completed on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract data specific to sleep and body image in order to assess how these factors are related and additional related factors that may contribute to this relationship.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Individual differences in the relationship between sleep and body image

other.value:
We may also conduct additional exploratory analyses using cluster analysis approaches (e.g. k-means, finite mixture models, finite mixture models of regression models) or similar to identify sub-groups of participants based on their self-reported sleep and their interoceptive accuracy scores. We will then seek to compare any sub-groups in their Body Acceptance subscale scores with corrections for multiple comparisons where relevant. Note, that in this context we may in future work also seek to explore additional items from the full Touch Test survey that are not mentioned as part of our planned analyses above. The purpose of this will be to take advantage of a large-scale data set with a view to promote future research avenues. For group comparisons we will remove any outliers that are three standard deviations away from the group average. We will also compare data with and without group outliers as a sensitivity analysis. Approaches for analysis will be constrained by data distribution with either parametric (e.g. ANOVA) or non-parametric alternatives (e.g. permutation tests) being used for comparison purposes.

Depending on sample characteristics we may also seek to run group level comparisons on variables of interest in relation to demographic differences (e.g. age, gender). This will depend upon the sample of size of participants recruited within these groups and likely form a separate specific project. If this becomes the case, further details on these analysis will be registered as an additional subproject once sample sizes have been ascertained after the data collection is completed and accessed (this is because we will not know participant numbers in each group until the survey is finished).

sample.value:
Our target sample size was calculated using G*Power software. Our goal was to obtain  sufficient sample size to run regression analyses with a maximum of 5 predictors, achieving .95 power to detect a medium effect size of f² = .15. Since we anticipate being able to recruit a large participant sample for the project, a more stringent alpha level of .01 was selected for the regression analysis. 

The ultimate sample sizes will be constrained by the period of data collection, which will run from 21/01/2020 – 30/03/2020. This period is fixed and dictated by the BBC, who have commissioned the project. Thus, our stopping criteria is restricted by date (30/03/2020).

analyses.value:
All analyses and statistical tests will be accompanied by reports of standardized effect size and 95% confidence intervals, where applicable.

Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and appropriate tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov). In the case of moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar will be conducted. In the cases of extreme deviations from normality, we will apply equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 

We will use the following alpha levels: <.005 for all correlations, <.01 given sample size for all regressions, <.05 for group level comparisons. 

Correlation and regression analysis:
We will examine the correlation between: body image, sleep quality, and interoception. We will us an alpha criterion of p <.005.

We will conduct separate regression models to assess how sleep relates to body image, with sleep, interoception, sleep*interoception interaction, age, gender, and week of testing included as predictor variables. Statistical significance will be assessed for the overall model, for R Square change, and for individual regressors with an alpha criterion of p < 0.01.

outliers.value:
Participants will need to have completed at least 80% of each scale or subscale for that data to be included in an analysis. Where less than 80% of items have been completed, data will be excluded. Subscales will be treated individually, where a participant may be excluded from analysis for one subscale, but can still be included in analyses for other subscales on that scale, where data is sufficient. If analysis focuses on a single item/question from the survey we will include all participants who complete the question

Depending on the data distribution, sleep variables could be dichotomised (e.g. if some categories are poorly endorsed). 

To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant.

dependent.value:
Our main dependent variables of interest is Body Image, which will be measured via scores on Dresden Body Image Questionnaire Body Acceptance Subscale. 

In some analyses we will also use sleep as a dependent variable. These can be broken into measures of sleep quality (items 1-5 below) and diurnal preference (item 6 below). 

1.	Sleep is measured with the following items: How would you rate your sleep quality for the majority of nights during the past month? (Overall Sleep Quality)
2.	During the majority of the days and nights in the past month how many hours of actual sleep did you get at night? This may be different to the number of hours you spent in bed. (Sleep Duration)
3.	Thinking about a typical night in the last month... How long does it take you to fall asleep? (Sleep Latency)
4.	If you then wake up during the night, how long are you awake in total (add up all the time when you are awake)? (Night Awakening)
5.	How many times did you wake up between the time you first fell asleep and your final awakening? (Times Awake)
6.	One hears about "morning" and "evening" types of people. Which one of these do you consider yourself to be? (Diurnal preference)

conditions.value:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales using an opportunity sample. Variables of interest for the current project are described above/below.

Participants to be included in the analysis will be asked to complete all of the measures. Participants have been recruited through broadcasts on the BBC and other media. There is no monetary incentive to take part. Participants must be aged over 18 years old and have internet access on a computer, smart phone or tablet to participate. Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. 


We will assess the following predictor variables to assess how they influence Body Image:

1. Sleep (using items 1-5 described in measurement of sleep above; i.e. item 1 will be a single regressor, item 2 will be a single regressor of interest) 
2. Interoception (using the Interoceptive Accuracy Scale - Murphy et al., 2020; measuring self-reported interoceptive accuracy -  the ability to accurately detect internal bodily sensations).
3. Age
4. Gender (to be dummy coded)
5. Point of testing: The data for this project have been collected during a period of escalating concern over Covid-19, which may influence responses. We will thus include the day or week of survey completion as a predictor variable in our regression analyses as a control variable. Definition of the use of day or week will be clearer once data are fully accessed as it will depend on number of sample points available in the data set.
6. Diurnal preference (measurement described above)

hypothesis.value:
We have the following questions (and predictions) that will be addressed:

1.	What is the relationship between sleep and body-image? We predict that better sleep quality (see dependent variables for measures linked to sleep quality) will be linked with more positive body image (measured using the Dresden Body Image Questionnaire Body Acceptance Subscale). 
2.	To what degree do individual differences in interoception contribute to relationships between sleep and body image? We predict that better interoception (see below for measure details) will be linked to better sleep quality. In particular we expect largest effect sizes on the following measures: Overall Sleep Quality, Sleep Latency, and Sleep Duration.  We also expect better interoception to be linked to more positive body image. We predict that relationships between sleep quality and interoception may predict individual differences in body image. 

Our survey is worldwide, but given the likely main UK base of participants we plan to restrict our analyses to the UK. Specifically, UK adults who do not report experience of long-term health conditions or impairments.

study_type_other.value: Since January 21 2020 we have been conducting a large global survey in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to close on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract data specific to sleep and body image in order to assess how these factors are related and additional related factors that may contribute to this relationship. As yet we have not accessed the full dataset and will not do so until the survey closes.

attributes.title: Associations between subjective sleep quality and touch in  an adult general population sample
attributes.description: This project will seek to explore the relationship between touch and subjective sleep quality in an adult population. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to be completed on 30th March 2020). As part of this cross sectional survey, data regarding sleep quality and quantity and diurnal preference are being collected. These are our primary dependent variables for this project. More specifically, we will extract data specific to touch, sleep quality and quantity, and additional variables that might be relevant to the relationship between touch and sleep.

q1.value: Anna Lena Dueren, Michael J. Banissy, Alice Gregory, Natalie Bowling, Aikaterini Vafeiadou

q2.value:
The following predictions will be examined in a UK adult sample, who do not report experience of long-term health conditions or impairments. 

Previous literature indicates that pleasant touch such as that experienced during sex and massage influences subjective sleep quality (Dittami et al., 2007, Owais et al., 2018; Pallesen et al., 2020). Interestingly, Pallesen et al. (2020) found gender differences in this association between sexual activity and sleep with men reporting different effects of sex on sleep depending on whether they reached orgasm or not, while this was not true for women. The relationship between sleep and other types of touch is less widely researched. However, cuddling and affective caressing have been found to have calming effects (van Anders et al., 2012; Triscoli, Croy, Olausson & Sailer, 2017) and young people in romantic relationships prefer to sleep in positions where they touch one another (Junker, Bergel, Deresko, Freund & Schredl, 2016). Furthermore, wider evidence indicates that bed sharing itself affects sleep quality (e.g. Troxel, Robles, Hall, Buysse, 2007; Troxel, 2010; Richter, Adam, Geiss, Peter & Niklewski; 2016). The broader literature has also shown that attitudes to and experiences of touch and sleep vary depending on individual differences, such as age (Sehlstedt et al., 2016), sexual preference (Chen & Shiu, 2017) gender (Trotter, McGlone, Reniers & Deakin, 2018), cultural background (e.g. Dibiase & Gunnoe, 2004) and attachment style (Adams, Stoops, Skomro, 2014; Adams & McWilliams, 2015; Krahé et al., 2018). Based on the previous literature around touch and sleep, several hypotheses are made:

Hypothesis 1.: We expect that bed sharing with touch will be reported to influence sleep quality, with mainly positive effects reported for six different types of touch that are investigated (see below for details) relative to negative and neutral effects of bed sharing without touch on subjective sleep quality.
Hypothesis 2.: We expect that respondents who experience more frequent touch in their everyday life will report differences in their subjective quality of sleep compared with those who experience less frequent touch.
Hypothesis 3.: We predict that respondents who report touch at bedtime in their childhood (measured by item 3 of the Touch Test TEAQ) will report better sleep quality as adults compared to those who do not report touch at bedtime in their childhood.
Hypothesis 4. (exploratory): We expect that the impact of touch on sleep quality may also be influenced by the following factors: age, gender, sexual preference, ethnicity and attachment (based on known differences in these groups related to touch and sleep in isolation).  

Note that for this study Sleep Quality is measured via responses to the following items: 

1. "How would you rate your sleep quality for the majority of nights during the past month?"(hereafter called Overall Sleep Quality)
2. "During the majority of the days and nights in the past month how many hours of actual sleep did you get at night? This may be different to the number of hours you spent in bed." (hereafter called Sleep Duration)
3. "Thinking about a typical night in the last month... How long does it take you to fall asleep?" (hereafter called Sleep Latency)
4. "If you then wake up during the night, how long are you awake in total (add up all the time when you are awake)?" (hereafter called Night Awakening)
5. "How many times did you wake up between the time you first fell asleep and your final awakening?" (hereafter called Times Awake)

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

The order of these variables was partly randomised between participants using Qualtrics survey software. The order of randomised blocks is provided in the attached document . Within particular scales, items were presented in a standard order to maintain consistency with prior work.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: Data collection for this project has already begun but is not yet completed. It is currently held online on the Qualtrics survey platform. The data will be accessed and analysed after data collection is completed on 30/03/2020.

question.value: Participants have been recruited through broadcasts on the BBC and other media. There is no monetary incentive to take part. Participants must be aged over 18 years old and have internet access on a computer, smart phone or tablet to participate.

q11.value: Our minimum required sample size consists of 1621 respondents. We will collect a large opportunity sample with the aim of recruiting at least this number of participants for each sample of interest. Note that our stopping criteria are restricted by date (30/03/2020) as the project is a collaboration with the BBC/Wellcome Collection and the stopping date is set by these partners. Based on similar prior projects run by BBC/Wellcome Collection we envisage a minimum sample of ~20,000 participants from the UK.

q12.value:
Our target sample size was calculated using G*Power software. Our goal was to obtain a sufficient sample size to run multiple regression analyses with a maximum of 11 predictors (the maximum number of variables in analysis to test hypotheses 2-4, see analysis plan), achieving .95 power to detect a small effect size of f² = .02 at .01 alpha error probability. 

The ultimate sample size will be constrained by the period of data collection, which will run from 21/01/2020 – 29/03/2020. This period is fixed and dictated by the BBC, who have commissioned the project.

Regarding the country of residence, at minimum we will conduct our study on participants from the UK (we anticipate this to be possible based upon previous survey studies of this kind run via BBC/Wellcome Collection). If possible we will also explore additional European and North American countries should suitable sample sizes be achieved. This will be clearer once data collection closes.

q13.value: Our stopping cirteria are restricted by date (30/03/2020) as the project is a collaboration with the BBC/Wellcome Collection and the stopping date is set by these partners.

question.value:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several separate scales. All variables of interest for the current project are described below. For a full list of survey contents, see attached document.

Demographic questions:
Age 
Gender
Sexual orientation 
Country of residence
(If UK) Ethnicity
Disability, long-term condition or impairment (will only be used to select respondents who do not indicate a disability, long-term condition or impairment)
Date of completion (will only be used as control variable concerning COVID-19 related changes in response patters)

We additionally extract the following variables related to sleep:


1. "How would you rate your sleep quality for the majority of nights during the past month?" (Overall Sleep Quality)
2. "During the majority of the days and nights in the past month how many hours of actual sleep did you get at night? This may be different to the number of hours you spent in bed." (Sleep Duration)
3. "Thinking about a typical night in the last month... How long does it take you to fall asleep?" (Sleep Latency)
4. "If you then wake up during the night, how long are you awake in total (add up all the time when you are awake)?" (Night Awakening)
5. "How many times did you wake up between the time you first fell asleep and your final awakening?" (Times Awake)
6. "One hears about "morning" and "evening" types of people. Which one of these do you consider yourself to be?" (diurnal preference)
7. Judgments of how different types of touch and bedsharing without touch are related to sleep quality (hereafter called Touch-Sleep Measure). Judgments are collected by asking participants to group touch/bedsharing descriptions to one of three possible answers. The three answer possibilities are: 
- “I think that it would have a negative effect on my sleep quality”
- “I think that it would have no effect on my sleep quality” 
- “I think that it would have a positive effect on my sleep quality”. 
Touch and bedsharing descriptors are: 
- A gentle stroke by your partner
- A short good-night hug from your partner
- A massage from your partner
- Intimate touch from your partner
- Preparing to sleep in a position in which you and your partner are touching one another
- Preparing to sleep in a position in which you are your partner are not touching one another

Touch and other scale measurement:

1. Anxiety and Avoidance in adult attachment. They are measured by a 12-item version of the Experiences in Close Relationships Questionnaire (ECR-12; Lafontaine et al., 2015).
2. Two items to measure current touch (hereafter called Current Touch):
 “When was the last time that somebody touched you intentionally, not including formal gestures such as handshakes in meetings?”. Item is answered on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from “In the last hour” to “Over a year ago”. 
"Thinking about the amount of touch in your life is it...”, answered on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from “Definitely too little” to “Definitely too much”. 
3. Loneliness, as measured with the UCLA Loneliness Scale (Russell, Peplau & Cutrona, 1980).
4. Childhood touch, as measured with one item from the TEAQ (Trotter et al., 2018): “As a child my parents would tuck me up in bed every night and give me a hug and a kiss goodnight.”, answered on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from "Disagree strongly" to "Agree strongly"
Items from ECR-12 and UCLA Loneliness Scale (described above) will be calculated as scale and subscale scores according to published scoring instructions.

Hypothesis 1: For each type of touch in the Touch-Sleep Measure we will report the proportion of people who report a negative effect, a positive effect or a neutral effect on sleep. This will be analysed for each item using Chi-Square tests. Adjusted residuals will be used to identify which pairs of cells differ significantly. The alpha level will be corrected for the number of comparisons. 

Hypothesis 2: We will group participants according to their scores on Current Touch. We will then compare the groups on sleep variables (Overall Sleep Quality; Sleep Duration; Sleep Latency; Night Awakening; Times Awake; Diurnal Preference) using ANOVAs, paired comparisons, and/or permutation tests where relevant (depending on data meeting test assumptions). The alpha level will be corrected for the number of comparisons where relevant.

We will also use regression analyses (e.g. multiple linear, ordinal logistic, or multivariate regression) to examine if Current Touch predicts sleep variables when controlling for variables: age, gender, loneliness, ethnicity, day/week of testing (to be defined based on sample characteristics after data is accessed), and Anxiety and Avoidance attachment. 

Hypothesis 3: We will group participants according to their scores on item 3 of the Touch Test TEAQ. We will then compare the groups on sleep variables (Overall Sleep Quality; Sleep Duration; Sleep Latency; Night Awakening; Times Awake; Diurnal Preference) using ANOVAs, paired comparisons, and/or permutation tests where relevant (depending on data meeting test assumptions). The alpha level will be corrected for the number of comparisons where relevant.

We will also use regression analyses (e.g. multiple linear, ordinal logistic, or multivariate regression) to examine if childhood touch predicts sleep variables when controlling for age, gender, loneliness, day/week of testing (to be defined based on sample characteristics after data is accessed), and Anxiety and Avoidance attachment.

q18.value:
Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and tests of normality (e.g. Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests). For moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar will be applied. For extreme deviations from normality, we will use equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 

For group comparisons we will remove any outliers that are three standard deviations away from the group average. We will also compare data with and without group outliers as a sensitivity analysis.

To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant.

Depending on the data distribution, sleep variables could be dichotomised (e.g. in cases where categories are poorly endorsed).

Gender will be included as a control variable in regression analyses described in the Analysis Plan. To achieve this, gender categories (recorded as Man, Non-Binary, Woman) will be dummy coded.

registration_responses.q1: Anna Lena Dueren, Michael J. Banissy, Alice Gregory, Natalie Bowling, Aikaterini Vafeiadou
registration_responses.q2:
The following predictions will be examined in a UK adult sample, who do not report experience of long-term health conditions or impairments. 

Previous literature indicates that pleasant touch such as that experienced during sex and massage influences subjective sleep quality (Dittami et al., 2007, Owais et al., 2018; Pallesen et al., 2020). Interestingly, Pallesen et al. (2020) found gender differences in this association between sexual activity and sleep with men reporting different effects of sex on sleep depending on whether they reached orgasm or not, while this was not true for women. The relationship between sleep and other types of touch is less widely researched. However, cuddling and affective caressing have been found to have calming effects (van Anders et al., 2012; Triscoli, Croy, Olausson & Sailer, 2017) and young people in romantic relationships prefer to sleep in positions where they touch one another (Junker, Bergel, Deresko, Freund & Schredl, 2016). Furthermore, wider evidence indicates that bed sharing itself affects sleep quality (e.g. Troxel, Robles, Hall, Buysse, 2007; Troxel, 2010; Richter, Adam, Geiss, Peter & Niklewski; 2016). The broader literature has also shown that attitudes to and experiences of touch and sleep vary depending on individual differences, such as age (Sehlstedt et al., 2016), sexual preference (Chen & Shiu, 2017) gender (Trotter, McGlone, Reniers & Deakin, 2018), cultural background (e.g. Dibiase & Gunnoe, 2004) and attachment style (Adams, Stoops, Skomro, 2014; Adams & McWilliams, 2015; Krahé et al., 2018). Based on the previous literature around touch and sleep, several hypotheses are made:

Hypothesis 1.: We expect that bed sharing with touch will be reported to influence sleep quality, with mainly positive effects reported for six different types of touch that are investigated (see below for details) relative to negative and neutral effects of bed sharing without touch on subjective sleep quality.
Hypothesis 2.: We expect that respondents who experience more frequent touch in their everyday life will report differences in their subjective quality of sleep compared with those who experience less frequent touch.
Hypothesis 3.: We predict that respondents who report touch at bedtime in their childhood (measured by item 3 of the Touch Test TEAQ) will report better sleep quality as adults compared to those who do not report touch at bedtime in their childhood.
Hypothesis 4. (exploratory): We expect that the impact of touch on sleep quality may also be influenced by the following factors: age, gender, sexual preference, ethnicity and attachment (based on known differences in these groups related to touch and sleep in isolation).  

Note that for this study Sleep Quality is measured via responses to the following items: 

1. "How would you rate your sleep quality for the majority of nights during the past month?"(hereafter called Overall Sleep Quality)
2. "During the majority of the days and nights in the past month how many hours of actual sleep did you get at night? This may be different to the number of hours you spent in bed." (hereafter called Sleep Duration)
3. "Thinking about a typical night in the last month... How long does it take you to fall asleep?" (hereafter called Sleep Latency)
4. "If you then wake up during the night, how long are you awake in total (add up all the time when you are awake)?" (hereafter called Night Awakening)
5. "How many times did you wake up between the time you first fell asleep and your final awakening?" (hereafter called Times Awake)

registration_responses.q12:
Our target sample size was calculated using G*Power software. Our goal was to obtain a sufficient sample size to run multiple regression analyses with a maximum of 11 predictors (the maximum number of variables in analysis to test hypotheses 2-4, see analysis plan), achieving .95 power to detect a small effect size of f² = .02 at .01 alpha error probability. 

The ultimate sample size will be constrained by the period of data collection, which will run from 21/01/2020 – 29/03/2020. This period is fixed and dictated by the BBC, who have commissioned the project.

Regarding the country of residence, at minimum we will conduct our study on participants from the UK (we anticipate this to be possible based upon previous survey studies of this kind run via BBC/Wellcome Collection). If possible we will also explore additional European and North American countries should suitable sample sizes be achieved. This will be clearer once data collection closes.

registration_responses.q15.question:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several separate scales. All variables of interest for the current project are described below. For a full list of survey contents, see attached document.

Demographic questions:
Age 
Gender
Sexual orientation 
Country of residence
(If UK) Ethnicity
Disability, long-term condition or impairment (will only be used to select respondents who do not indicate a disability, long-term condition or impairment)
Date of completion (will only be used as control variable concerning COVID-19 related changes in response patters)

We additionally extract the following variables related to sleep:


1. "How would you rate your sleep quality for the majority of nights during the past month?" (Overall Sleep Quality)
2. "During the majority of the days and nights in the past month how many hours of actual sleep did you get at night? This may be different to the number of hours you spent in bed." (Sleep Duration)
3. "Thinking about a typical night in the last month... How long does it take you to fall asleep?" (Sleep Latency)
4. "If you then wake up during the night, how long are you awake in total (add up all the time when you are awake)?" (Night Awakening)
5. "How many times did you wake up between the time you first fell asleep and your final awakening?" (Times Awake)
6. "One hears about "morning" and "evening" types of people. Which one of these do you consider yourself to be?" (diurnal preference)
7. Judgments of how different types of touch and bedsharing without touch are related to sleep quality (hereafter called Touch-Sleep Measure). Judgments are collected by asking participants to group touch/bedsharing descriptions to one of three possible answers. The three answer possibilities are: 
- “I think that it would have a negative effect on my sleep quality”
- “I think that it would have no effect on my sleep quality” 
- “I think that it would have a positive effect on my sleep quality”. 
Touch and bedsharing descriptors are: 
- A gentle stroke by your partner
- A short good-night hug from your partner
- A massage from your partner
- Intimate touch from your partner
- Preparing to sleep in a position in which you and your partner are touching one another
- Preparing to sleep in a position in which you are your partner are not touching one another

Touch and other scale measurement:

1. Anxiety and Avoidance in adult attachment. They are measured by a 12-item version of the Experiences in Close Relationships Questionnaire (ECR-12; Lafontaine et al., 2015).
2. Two items to measure current touch (hereafter called Current Touch):
 “When was the last time that somebody touched you intentionally, not including formal gestures such as handshakes in meetings?”. Item is answered on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from “In the last hour” to “Over a year ago”. 
"Thinking about the amount of touch in your life is it...”, answered on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from “Definitely too little” to “Definitely too much”. 
3. Loneliness, as measured with the UCLA Loneliness Scale (Russell, Peplau & Cutrona, 1980).
4. Childhood touch, as measured with one item from the TEAQ (Trotter et al., 2018): “As a child my parents would tuck me up in bed every night and give me a hug and a kiss goodnight.”, answered on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from "Disagree strongly" to "Agree strongly"
registration_responses.q16.question: Items from ECR-12 and UCLA Loneliness Scale (described above) will be calculated as scale and subscale scores according to published scoring instructions.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Hypothesis 1: For each type of touch in the Touch-Sleep Measure we will report the proportion of people who report a negative effect, a positive effect or a neutral effect on sleep. This will be analysed for each item using Chi-Square tests. Adjusted residuals will be used to identify which pairs of cells differ significantly. The alpha level will be corrected for the number of comparisons. 

Hypothesis 2: We will group participants according to their scores on Current Touch. We will then compare the groups on sleep variables (Overall Sleep Quality; Sleep Duration; Sleep Latency; Night Awakening; Times Awake; Diurnal Preference) using ANOVAs, paired comparisons, and/or permutation tests where relevant (depending on data meeting test assumptions). The alpha level will be corrected for the number of comparisons where relevant.

We will also use regression analyses (e.g. multiple linear, ordinal logistic, or multivariate regression) to examine if Current Touch predicts sleep variables when controlling for variables: age, gender, loneliness, ethnicity, day/week of testing (to be defined based on sample characteristics after data is accessed), and Anxiety and Avoidance attachment. 

Hypothesis 3: We will group participants according to their scores on item 3 of the Touch Test TEAQ. We will then compare the groups on sleep variables (Overall Sleep Quality; Sleep Duration; Sleep Latency; Night Awakening; Times Awake; Diurnal Preference) using ANOVAs, paired comparisons, and/or permutation tests where relevant (depending on data meeting test assumptions). The alpha level will be corrected for the number of comparisons where relevant.

We will also use regression analyses (e.g. multiple linear, ordinal logistic, or multivariate regression) to examine if childhood touch predicts sleep variables when controlling for age, gender, loneliness, day/week of testing (to be defined based on sample characteristics after data is accessed), and Anxiety and Avoidance attachment.

attributes.title: Individual differences in the relationship between empathy, touch, and wellbeing.
attributes.description: This project will seek to explore the relationship between touch, empathy, and both social and non-social wellbeing across different cohorts of the UK population. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to be completed on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract data specific to touch, empathy and social and non-social wellbeing (alongside demographic variables) in order to assess how these factors are related and interact with each other.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Individual differences in the relationship between empathy, touch, and wellbeing.

other.value: We may also decide to conduct two forms of secondary analysis. 1) An in depth moderation analysis to more thoroughly explore the moderating effect touch may have on the relationship between empathy and wellbeing (which will be initially assessed using interaction terms in the regression analyses—described above). 2) An exploratory analysis to identify responder subgroups using cluster analysis techniques (e.g. k-means, finite mixture models, finite mixtures of regression models). The purpose of this will be to take advantage of a large dataset on mental and social wellbeing in relation to touch and empathy. It will provide future researchers with a detailed taxonomy of individual differences in the nomological network of touch, empathy, and wellbeing. Our hope is that this will provide a foundation for strong empirical research within the field, helping other scientists to identify useful avenues of research and formulate hypotheses. Note, that in this context we may in future work also seek to explore additional items from the full Touch Test survey (please see attached file) that are not mentioned as part of our planned analyses above.

sample.value: Our target sample size is a minimum of 954 for each sample that we plan to analyse in our regressions. We will collect a large opportunity sample with the aim of recruiting at least this number of participants for each sample of interest. This sample was determined using a power calculation in G*Power, performed to determine the minimum number of observations required to perform a multiple linear regression with 15 predictor variables to detect small effect sizes (i.e. f2=0.02, α = .05, β = .80). Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. Based on similar prior projects run by BBC/Wellcome Collection we envisage a minimum sample of ~20,000 participants from the UK.

analyses.value:
All analyses and statistical tests will be accompanied by reports of standardized effect size and 95% confidence intervals, where applicable

Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and appropriate tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov). In the case of moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar will be applied. In the cases of extreme deviations from normality, we will apply equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 

We will use the following alpha levels: <.05 for all correlations (which will be corrected for the total number of correlations that are run), <.01 given sample size for all regressions.

Correlation and regression analysis:
We will examine the correlations between: empathy, touch, attachment styles, wellbeing and loneliness scales. We predict that there will be positive associations between: empathy-TEAQ, empathy-mental wellbeing, TEAQ-mental wellbeing, STQ-loneliness. We predict negative  associations between: empathy-STQ, STQ-mental wellbeing, empathy-loneliness, TEAQ-loneliness. We will us an alpha criterion of .05 that will be corrected for the total number of correlations that are run.

We will conduct separate multiple linear regression models to assess how both touch and empathy measures relate to mental wellbeing and loneliness, with empathy, touch subscales, empathy*touch interaction, attachment style subscales, age, gender, and week of testing included as predictor variables. Statistical significance will be assessed for the overall model, for R Square change, and for individual regressors with an alpha criterion of p < 0.01.

outliers.value:
To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant.

Participants will need to have completed at least 80% of each scale or subscale for that data to be included in an analysis. Where less than 80% of items have been completed, data will be excluded. Subscales will be treated individually, where a participant may be excluded from analysis for one subscale, but can still be included in analyses for other subscales on that scale, where data is sufficient. If analysis focuses on a single item/question from the survey we will include all participants who complete the question.

dependent.value: Our main dependent variables of interest are mental and social wellbeing, which will be measured via scores on the Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (Stewart-Brown, 2009) and UCLA Loneliness Scale (Russell, 1996) respectively.

conditions.value:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales using an opportunity sample. Variables of interest for the current project are described above/below.

Participants to be included in the analysis will be asked to complete all of the measures. Participants have been recruited through broadcasts on the BBC and other media. There is no monetary incentive to take part. Participants must be aged over 18 years old and have internet access on a computer, smart phone or tablet to participate. Note, there is a fixed stopping criteria which is the date set for survey completion by the BBC/Wellcome Collection – namely 30th March 2020. 

We will assess the following predictor variables to assess how they influence wellbeing:
1.	Empathy: a modified version of the Empathy Quotient Questionnaire (Muncer and Ling, 2006; EQ)—using scores from the emotional reactivity and cognitive empathy subscales.

2.	Attitudes towards and experience of touch: 12 items selected from the Touch Attitudes and Experiences Questionnaire (TEAQ; Trotter et al., 2018), examining touch attitudes and experiences. These items represent six subscales relating to: Childhood Touch, Friends and Family Touch, Current Intimate Touch, Attitude to Intimate Touch, Attitude to Self-Care, and Attitude to Unfamiliar Touch. The Social Touch questionnaire (Wilhelm et al., 2001) produces a single total score and measuring attitudes towards social touch. Responses from a Portuguese sample have previously identified three underlying subscales, representing Dislike of Physical Touch, Liking of Familiar Physical Touch, and Liking of Public Physical Touch (Vieira et al, 2016).

3.	Age

4.	Gender

5.	Attachment style: Experiences in Close Relationship Scale-Short Form (Wei, 2007); Measures two subscales: Anxiety and Avoidance. Attachment style has been shown to be related to measures of wellbeing, we will thus include these subscale scores as predictor variables in our regression analyses as a control variables.

6.	Week of testing: The data for this project have been collected during a period of escalating concern over Covid-19, which may influence responses. We will thus include the week of survey completion as a predictor variable in our regression analyses as a control variable.

hypothesis.value:
We have the following questions (and predictions) that will be addressed:

1.	What is the relationship between touch and empathy? We predict that there will be a positive relationship between self-report attitudes towards, and experience of, touch (measured using the Social Touch Questionnaire and the Touch Experiences and Attitudes Questionnaire) and self-report empathy (measured using subscales from a modified/short version of the Empathy Quotient questionnaire).

2.	What is the relationship between touch, empathy, and wellbeing? We predict that there will be a positive relationship between empathy and both social wellbeing (operationalised as a negative relationship with scores on the UCLA Loneliness Scale), and non-social (mental) wellbeing (operationalised as a positive relationship with scores on the Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Wellbeing Scale). Similarly, we predict touch will be positively linked to both social and mental wellbeing.

3.	Does experience of and attitudes towards touch moderate empathy’s relationship with wellbeing? If touch and empathy both relate to each other, and to measures of wellbeing independently, we will examine the extent to which empathy-wellbeing relationships are dependant on an interaction with experiences of and attitudes towards touch.

Our survey is worldwide, but given the likely main UK base of participants we plan to  restrict our analyses to the UK. Specifically, UK adults who do not report experience of long-term health conditions or impairments.

study_type_other.value: Additional Information related to Data Collection: Since January 21 2020 we have been conducting a large global survey in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to be completed on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract data specific to empathy, touch, and wellbeing in order to assess how these factors are related and additional related factors that may contribute to this relationship. As yet we have not accessed the full dataset and will not do so until the survey closes.

We have the following questions (and predictions) that will be addressed:

1.	What is the relationship between touch and empathy? We predict that there will be a positive relationship between self-report attitudes towards, and experience of, touch (measured using the Social Touch Questionnaire and the Touch Experiences and Attitudes Questionnaire) and self-report empathy (measured using subscales from a modified/short version of the Empathy Quotient questionnaire).

2.	What is the relationship between touch, empathy, and wellbeing? We predict that there will be a positive relationship between empathy and both social wellbeing (operationalised as a negative relationship with scores on the UCLA Loneliness Scale), and non-social (mental) wellbeing (operationalised as a positive relationship with scores on the Short Warwick–Edinburgh Mental Wellbeing Scale). Similarly, we predict touch will be positively linked to both social and mental wellbeing.

3.	Does experience of and attitudes towards touch moderate empathy’s relationship with wellbeing? If touch and empathy both relate to each other, and to measures of wellbeing independently, we will examine the extent to which empathy-wellbeing relationships are dependant on an interaction with experiences of and attitudes towards touch.

Our survey is worldwide, but given the likely main UK base of participants we plan to  restrict our analyses to the UK. Specifically, UK adults who do not report experience of long-term health conditions or impairments.
registration_responses.study_type_other: Additional Information related to Data Collection: Since January 21 2020 we have been conducting a large global survey in collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection. The data will be drawn from a large survey that we are currently conducting collaboration with the BBC and Wellcome Collection (to be completed on 30th March 2020). There are a variety of measures in the survey, but for this project we will extract data specific to empathy, touch, and wellbeing in order to assess how these factors are related and additional related factors that may contribute to this relationship. As yet we have not accessed the full dataset and will not do so until the survey closes.

attributes.title: The Impact of rank salience on choice
attributes.description: In this study we are going to investigate whether due to rank salience (alternative rankings), the participants might choose the inferior, but rank salient alternative rather than one of the other two expected value maximizing alternatives.

q2.value:
Our main hypothesis is regarding the initial choice rate of the rank salient – “C” alternative. 
We hypothesize, that although this is the alternative with the lowest expected value (EV= 20.47), which is 10% below alternative “A” and “B” (EV=22.75), because alternative “C” is the rank salient one (appears most often in the “best two” ranking), it will be chosen more often than alternatives “A” and “B”.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The experiment will include choice between two stocks (A & B), and a Mutual Fund C, which is the average of the return of the two stocks minus the management fee (of 10%). The participants (who will be recruited through MTurk) will be presented with 101 payoff realizations of each of the alternatives, as presented in the attached choices.jpg file. They will make 100 repeated choices between the three alternatives (“A”, “B” & “C”).  Following each choice, the participants will be presented with one randomly selected realization of their chosen alternative.

attributes.title: Processing of intraclausal garden-path structures in Czech
attributes.description: In this experiment, we would like to test how native Czech speakers understand garden-path sentences. We will measure the response accuracy for three types of open-ended comprehension questions which will follow either a garden-path or a control sentence: a) question targeting the initial misanalysis, b) question targeting the sentence subject, c) question targeting the locative adjunct. We predict that the garden-path structure should lead to lower response accuracy in general and the rate of incorrect answers should thus be higher not only in the case of questions targeting the initial misanalysis, but in the case of the two other questions as well.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Intra-clausal garden-path sentences processing in native speakers of Czech: additional comprehension questions

sample.value:
Responses from about 70 participants gathered via online distribution will be collected. Only native speakers of Czech will be included in the data analysis (simultaneous bilinguals with Czech as one of the native languages will be also excluded). This number was set in advance as a compromise between sufficient power and resources available to the authors.
Altogether, there will be 24 experimental items and 96 filler sentences (24 of these will be used as experimenal sentences for a different experiment). Each participant will therefore read 120 sentences in random order during the experiment.

analyses.value:
The data will be analyzed using linear mixed models with the following structure:
   1) Reaction times: reaction time (transformed based on the Box-Cox test) as a dependent variable, sentence condition and response correctness as fixed effects, item and participant as random effects
   2) Response correctness: response as dependent variable, type of sentence (garden-path or non-garden-path) as fixed effect, item and participant as random effects.  

Incorrect answers will be classified into the following categories:
a) "I don't know" - participant explicitly states he does not know or remember the answer
b) Incomplete - participant's answer does not include the syntactic unit required by the question or does so in an unclear or indefinite way
c) Garden-path - participant's answer might be a result of a lingering misanalysis (cases when participant explicitly offers both the correct and incorrect analysis as an answer,  e.g. "Co udělal organizátor" -> "vykázal z šatny sportovkyni/trenérku" are also categorized as garden-path) 
d) Substitution 
I. Formal - target word is replaced by a word with similar form but different meaning
II. Transfer-intra - target word is replaced by a (usually formally different) word from the same item (the form of the word might be secondarily altered by the participant to match the target word, e.g. "sluha" -> "služebník", target word = "panovník")
III. Transfer-inter - target word is replaced by a (usually formally similar) word form different item 
e) Rest - semantically distant answers (e. g. "rozesmát" -> "rozbrečet"); changes of syntactical structure (e. g. "vypátral panovníka v ruinách města" -> "vypátral panovníka města"); answers without any obvious connection to the target word (e. g. "vědec" -> "socha")

outliers.value:
Participants' response correctness on filler sentences will be measured and those who will score below 70% correct will be excluded from the analyses. 
The reaction times will be trimmed very conservatively, only those data points that were clearly discontinuous in the distribution will be removed.

dependent.value:
The study is designed as a self-paced reading experiment (sentence will be presented as a whole). Participants will be presented with an experimental item followed by an open comprehension question. Ibex farm will be used as presentation software. There are two dependent variables of interest:
   1) Reaction times for each sentence in milliseconds.
   2) Response correctness (measured as the proportion of correct answers to comprehension questions).

conditions.value:
The experiment has a 2×3 within-subject design. There are two independent variables.
1) Sentence type – garden-path and non-garden-path; manipulated by a change of grammatical gender of the noun in critical region resulting in potential local syntactic ambiguity (feminine = garden-path, masculine = non-garden-path).
2) Question type – object-oriented, subject-oriented and adverbial-oriented open ended questions. 

 
Item example:
A) GP + object-oriented question: "Policista zatkl obchodnici na nádraží kamarádku, když přijel mezinárodní expres." + "Co udělal policista?"
B) GP + subject-oriented question: "Policista zatkl obchodnici na nádraží kamarádku, když přijel mezinárodní expres." + "Kdo zatkl kamarádku?"
C) GP + adverbial-oriented question: "Policista zatkl obchodnici na nádraží kamarádku, když přijel mezinárodní expres." + "Kde se to stalo?"

D) Non-GP + object-oriented question: "Policista zatkl obchodníkovi na nádraží kamarádku, když přijel mezinárodní expres." + "Co udělal policista?"
E) Non-GP + subject-oriented question: "Policista zatkl obchodníkovi na nádraží kamarádku, když přijel mezinárodní expres." + "Kdo zatkl kamarádku?"
F) GP + adverbial-oriented question: "Policista zatkl obchodníkovi na nádraží kamarádku, když přijel mezinárodní expres." + "Kde se to stalo?"

hypothesis.value:
The main question is how native Czech speakers understand garden-path sentences. 
According to the good-enough approach to sentence processing, the (wrong) initial representation of garden-path sentence lingers and participants thus tend to produce more incorrect answers to comprehension questions targeting the initial misanalysis (object-oriented questions in our case) than they do in the case of non-garden path sentences. Other regions of the garden-path sentence should be understood correctly.
According to previous findings of J. Chromý, the garden-path structure leads to worse sentence comprehension in general and the rate of incorrect answers should thus be higher not only in the case of object-oriented questions but in the case of questions targeting other syntactic sentence regions as well.

attributes.title: Resource science and governance
attributes.description: We present the analysis of the state of the global natural resource base through the lens of the planetary health while designing the alliance of life sciences, legal and political studies, and the big data science. We set up priorities in both resource science and governance and suggest instruments and steps in closing the resource-health policy gap. This is a timely and unavoidable endeavor in the current context topped by the combined synergic 2008 and 2020 pandemics crises.

summary.value:
The Communication in attachment is to be registered
Nature’s goods and services are the ultimate foundation of life and health. As a consequence,
humans are strongly health-minded, and are individually and collectively resource-driven.
However, humans do not frame resources properly, as the environmental crisis reflects the
unsustainable management of resources, the landmark of the Anthropocene. Current governance systems are not equipped to handle challenges such as the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals, as resource governance across sectors does not exist. Radical
changes in resource governance and allocation are proposed by designing a resource systems
approach that integrates three indivisible principles (elaborated as a new framework of convergence between social and ecological processes) with the concept of planetary health
(health for individuals, societies and ecosystems). To facilitate their operationalization and
social acceptance, a resource-centered science is integrated within the framework. The goal
of the resource-centered science is to translate and incorporate this framework into knowledge-led approaches and scientific evidence-based decision-making, and to experimentally define new objects of law and new forms of institutions. The framework targets strong sustainability through the stewardship of the common resource base and promotes resource justice and environmental responsibility in the public interest. Ongoing programs, practices, experimentations or initiatives indicate that this resource approach is timely and feasible.

attributes.title: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) and Pregnancy: A Systematic Review
attributes.description: This review will assess the maternal, fetal, and neonatal outcomes in women with COVID-19.

q1.value: Ziyi Yang, Ziyu Zhu, Min Wang, Yi Liu

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: A search was performed on March 26, 2020 using PubMed, MedRxiv, CNKI, Wanfang Data, VIP, and CBMdisc. Studies reporting maternal, fetal, and neonatal outcomes in women with COVID-19 were considered for inclusion. We put no restrictions on language. Two researchers independently selected studies, and extracted relavant data into a predefined data extraction form.
Any maternal, fetal, and neonatal outcomes will be measured.

q23.value:
1. Quality assessment for case reports and case series
To assess the quality of case reports and case series, a modified version of a tool for quality appraisal of case reports and case series will be used. Four domains comprising five questions are included in the assessment tool: (1) Selection: does the patient(s) represent(s) the whole experience of the investigator (center) or is the selection method unclear to the extent that other patients with similar presentation may not have been reported? (2) Ascertainment: was the exposure adequately ascertained? Was the outcome adequately ascertained? (3) Causality: was follow-up long enough for outcomes to occur? (4) Reporting: is the case(s) described with sufficient details to allow other investigators to replicate the research or to allow practitioners make inferences related to their own practice? Possible item ranking were yes (2 stars), partial (1 star), and no (0 star). Studies rated with more than 7 stars were considered high-quality. Any discrepancies in quality assessment were discussed and resolved by three authors.

2. Novel Coronavirus Pneumonia Diagnosis and Treatment Plan
Clinical classifications:
(1) Mild form.
Clinical symptoms are minor, imaging does not show signs of lung inflammation.
(2) Regular form.
Has fever and respiratory tract symptoms, imaging shows visible lung inflammation.
(3) Severe form.
Adults who meet any one of the following:
Shortness of breath, RR > 30 breaths/minute; 2. Oxygen saturation < 93% at rest
Arterial oxygen partial pressure (PaO2)/ fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) < 300mmHg (1mmHg=0.133kPa).
For high altitude (altitude over 1000 meters) regions, (PaO2/FiO2) should be corrected according to the following formula: PaO2/FiO2 x [ atmospheric pressure (mmHg)/760]
The patient should be managed as a severe case if lung imaging shows a substantial progression of lesions (greater than 50%) within 24-48 hours.
(4) Critical form. Meeting any of the following criteria:
Respiratory failure occurs and mechanical ventilation is required;
Shock;
Combined failure of other organs that requires ICU monitoring.

3.Search strategy can be found in the datasets (Mendeley Data)

attributes.title: Protocol for a scoping review on the prevalence and impact of combined vision and hearing (dual sensory) impairment

summary.value: Hearing and vision impairments are common globally. These two sensory impairments are often considered separately in research as well as in planning and delivering services. However, hearing and vision impairment can occur concurrently, which is often termed dual sensory impairment (DSI). Although the prevalence and impact of hearing and vision impairment as single impairments has been examined in depth, data are lacking on DSI. The aim of this scoping review is to determine the nature and extent of the evidence on the prevalence and impact of DSI.
